document.text: The eleventh annual reunion of the old Confederates who fought under Col. John S. Mosby was held at Ber- ryville, near which place during the war Mosbys men made many daring exploits. The meeting was presided over by Col. Joseph Bryan, of Rich mond. Hon. Marshall McCormick de livered the address of welcome and a memorial from the pen of Col. John Alexander, of Leesburg, on the death of Chaplain Sidney Ferguson was read. J. William Foster was elected president and H. S. Ashby adjutant. The reunion closed tonight with an entertainment by Polk Miller and his Old South Quartet. At its regular meeting Garland Rodes Camp, Sons of Veterans, of Lynchburg, selected as their sponsor for the coming Confederate reunion Miss Rebecca Martin and as maid of honor Miss Norvie Craighill. both of that city. The Veterans have invited ex-Gov. Francis T. Nichols, who is spending the summer at Chase City, to attend the reunion and be one of the speakers. _ A call was issued by George E. Caskie, chairman of the executive committee of the Virginia Sunday- School Association, for the-State con vention to be held at Lynchburg Oc tober 3 to 5 . A large number of local committees will go to work at once arid arrange for a large attend ance. The last State convention was hqld at Petersburg in March, 1902.   George W. Wilson, of Fancy Hill, Rockbridge county, aged 73 years, is dead. He was a descendant of the Wilsons of Tinkling Springs, Augusta county, and had traveled over the whole of the United States. James Norton, of Medford,_ Mass., has discovered what he claimi to be the richest nickel mine in the United States on the edge of Floyd county, 10 miles south o f ShaWsville, on the Norfolk and Western railway. The lead is said to be large and Mr. Norton has ordered machinery for de veloping the property. The find is- lo cated four miles from the property of the United States Arsenic Mines Com pany, which is being operated by Pittsburg capitalists. The City Engineer, of Roanoke, is sued a building permit to the Norfolk and Western Railway for the erection of a new passenger station in that city at an estimated cost of 99,000. The Roanoke City Council enacted a Pure Food and Milk law. A drastic anti-gambling ordinance just enacted by the Roanoke City Council provides for a fine of not less than 50 nor more than 500 fot gaming. Mayor Cutchin says that he will permit no games of chance at the Roanoke fair in September. Mayor Joel H. Cutchin, of Roanoke, who was recently re-elected, in an in terview said he had given his time, attention and very best efforts to the city for two years and that his poli tical opponents have made the posi tion as unpleasant as possible. The Council, he says, has continually fought him in everything he attempts to do in the interest of the city, and recent proceedings he fears is an in dication that the same tactics will con tinue in the new Council. If so, he cannot and will not stand it. Some whom he thought were. his friends have shown an animosity that does not please him. He says the salary, which is less than any officer, police man or blacksmith of the city, is no compensation for the duties he is called upon to perform, to say nothing of a continual wrangle with the Coun cil, which is annoying to him and humiliating and distasteful to his rela tives and family. The Mayor says that the office has destroyed his law business and the continued harassing has injured his health and peace of mind. He says that if present condi tions continue no gentleman can- or will be Mayor of Roanoke. W. E. Ehoflf, 26 years old, is under arrest at Newport News on the charge of housebreaking, committed nearly six years ago. Ehoff was then living with his parents in Newport News. When he learned that a warrant had been sworn out against him he went to Philadelphia. While living there he was married, and a few days ago reappeared in Newport News with two children. The celebrated suit for divorce of Mrs. Olivia Thurman from her hus band, Gen. Charles Thurman, a rich landowner of Clarke county, which has been before the public frequently during the last year, was settled out of court. A decree will be entered giving Mrs. Thurman a divorce a mens et thoro, which will become absolute in three years, when alimony will cease. Caroline County Camp of Confed erate Veterans has decided to raise 2,500 for the erection of a monument to the Confederate soldiers of that county who were killed or died in the service. Rev. A. C. Knibb. a ministerial stu dent at the Virginia Christian Colege, of Lynchburg, has been conducting a protracted meeting in a tent in West Lynchburg for six weeks and nearly 300 persons have professed conver sion. About 200 persons have been baptized and many others will receive the ordinance-in a day or two. A broken axle wrecked n ears of a freight train on the Atlantic Coast line near Emnoria. No one was hurt. Mrs. R. L. Pownell, of Sherman dis trict. near Romney, was badly scald ed in the face while boiling hops. document.text: Rev. John Ward, 78 years old, a well- known Baptist clergyman of Isle ol Wight county, was found dead in bed. Mr. Ward, who was chaplain of the Cal- ott-Wrenn Camp of Confederate Vet erans, delivered the prayer at Isle ol Wight Courthouse -uesday, when the Confederate monument was unveiled in the presence of 4,000 persons. He was in his usual health at bed time. The deceased is survived by a widow and two sons Dr. J. W. Ward and Robert Ward. As the result of an accident on May IO, when he was bruised internally by being thrown from a buggy, Frank E- Stallings, a justice of the peace, at Buckhorn, Nanseniond county, dit-i iged 50 years. Justice Stallings horse became frightened at a pile-driver, and he jumped to escape more serious dam- ige. Mrs. ouise Fletcher oreene, of Rap pahannock, has been appointed to rep resent the Valley of .Virginia at the reunion of Confederate veterans to be held in Louisville this month. She lias selected Miss Brucie Funkhouser, of Strasburg, as her maid of honor. Major F. R. Lassiter sued the city of Petersburg for 3,560 because the ity erected a smallpox hospital on a farm adjoining his estate. J. C. Reed, of Evansville, Ind., was held in Petersburg charged with being passer of bogus checks. A syndicate has been formed to bund an electric railway to connect Ocean View and Pine Beach. The distance is ave miles, but 300,000 capital will be raised to build hotels and cottages along he line. Stewart Terry, the 15-year-otd son of Mr. W. L. Terry, a well to-do farmer, living near Lynchburg, was kicked by horse and is probably fatally injured. Jose Antone Peria, a fireman on the steamer City of Augusta, which has taken the place of the Hamilton between Norfolk and New York, is in St. Vin cents Hospital, Norfolk, seriously wounded, and Eugene Lianas, a Portu guese mess boy on the same steamer, is in jail charged with attacking him. The boys fought. Perias wounds are in the shoulder and were inflicted with a sharp carving knife. , A dispatch from King William Court house says that Henry Lipscomb, a farm er of Manquin, that county, is probably fatally injured as the result of an attack made on him with a pitchfork by a small negro boy. The boy became angered at something said to him by Lipscomb, and attacked the farmer, driving the fork into his body 15 timds. The reunion of Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the Valley, under the auspices of the lodges of Shenandoah county, occurred at Mount Jackson There were about 1,500 persons present. Dr. C. A. R. - Moore, Mayor of Mount Jackson, made the address of welcome This was followed by a speech of ReV E. E. Northern, past grand master of Winchester, upon the origin and growth of the Order of Odd Fellows. Mr. F. P. Brumback, of Woodstock, introduced the orator of the day, Gov. A. J. Mon tague, who made a splendid speech on Odd Fellowship, which was enthusias tically received. Sands  Oliver, contractors for the first 100 miles of the Tidewater railway, have begun clearing the rights of way at Suffolk for the roadbed. Managet Dupuy is ready to advertise for bids fot another section of the road. Thomas S. Nunnally and George By rum were indicted in the Corporatioi Court at Norfolk for non-support. Nun nally was required to give bond of 120 to insure the payment to his wife of 30 every three months, and Byrum was re quired to give a bond of 150 for the payment of 3 a week to his wife. Th order in each instance is to remain in force for 12 months, with the alterna tive of staying in jail. John P. Branch, one of Richmond wealthiest bankers, has giveh 30,000 to Randolph-Macon College, at Ashland, to be used in the erection of a dormi tory. Mr. Branch is a stanch friend of the college and has heretofore made large donations. Concluding a six days trial in the Circuit Court of Surry county, the 5,000 damage suit of James H. Dillard against Mayor George H. Woods and Police Chief Kemtnerer, of Claremont, ended in a mistrial. The suit was warmly contested by five attorneys. Dillard seeks damages because of alleged illegal arrest on account of his refusal to pay town license claims. Laughton Diuguid, aged 22 years, son of William D. Diuguid, a prominent bus iness man of Lynchburg, killed himself at his home shortly before noon by blow ing the top of his head off with a Win chester rifle. The young man was suf fering from nervous breakdown, caused by overstudy during the past term at school in Philadelphia, where he was taking a course in chemistry. He had to return home some weeks ago and was to be taken to Richmond for special treatment. He did not want to leave home, and the departure was delayed. Diuguid secured the rifle, went to hts room, and, placing the muzzle against his right temple, fired. The Elks have begun the erection of their  Home, on High street, Char lottesville, opposite the Courthouse. United States Marshal Morgan Treat will remove the headquarters of the Eastern district from Newport News to Richmond. The Merchants and Farmers Bank has been organized at Smithfield, with 30,000 to 50,000 capital stock. The officers are W. P. Wilson, president B. P. Gay, vice-president W. R. My ers, cashier.

Daniel and Gen eral Fitzhugh Lee returned yester day afternoon from Gape Charles, where they bare been attending a Confederate Veterans reunion. They expressed themselves as very much pleased with their trip. Speaking of the Senators stop in that city, the Richmond Dispatch says Senator John W. Daniel, who has been spending several days at Cape Charles, where he spoke at a Con federate reuuion on Thursday, ar rived in the city last night, and is stopping at Murphys. The Senator was seen by a Dis patch man and asked for an expres sion as to the political outlook, but pleaded ignorance of the situation as an excuse for not complying. He says he had devoted his entire time to legal business this summer, and consequently was not well posted in the doings of the political world I am going home now, though, he said, and prepare myself, and on the 7th of October I shall enter the legislative campaign at Franklin. The Senator thought the prospects for Democratic success in Virginia this fall were very bright, but when asked whether the brightness of the prospects extended beyond the hori zon of this State, he did not reply so readily. He thought, how ever, there was no occasion for Dem ocrats to worry about results, either immediate or prospective. During the course of the inter view the reporter alluded to the re solutions adopted by the convention being held throughout the State en dorsing Major Daniel, and the Sena tor said that they were all very gratifying to him.News.

document.text: Since the death of Rev. Dr. Malcolm MacVicar the Virginia Union Univer sity, near Richmond, has been without a president. Information has just been received that the executive board of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, which controls the institution, held a meeting in New York, and ap pointed Dr. George Rice Hovey to fill the place temporarily. The prospects are that he will be made president permanently. Dr. Hovey has been connected with the university for some years. He is a man of exceptional ability. The Virginia Union Univer sity is situated just outside the north ern boundaries of Richmond.  It has a number of splendid buildings and is doing a great work for the colored race. J. W. Adcock, of Amherst county, who was employed in the Buena Vista furnace yard on the cinder dump, was, a few nights ago, run over by the cinder engine and both of his legs mashed. It is thought that he was asleep, as no one saw him when the accident took place. His left leg was amputated above the ankle and it is thought that the other one will also have to be taken off. While a freight train was engaged in shifting on the Atlantic Coast Line, in Manchester, a car loaded with lum ber weighing 30,000 pounds broke away, tore the track to pieces and rushed into - Perry street, narrowly missing a crowded street car and scattering pedestrians right and left. The car toppled over and strewed the street with lumber. The Neff-Rice Camp, Confederate Verterans, held their annual reunion near Newmarket. Lieut. Gov. Joseph Willard, of Fairfax, Hon. Henry Downing, of Warren, Col. E. E. Stick- ley and Mr. Gilbert Pence, of Shenan doah, delivered addresses. A numbet of camps and several thousand peo ple were present. Robert Lee, white, 30 years old and unmarried, who said his home was al Columbia, N. C., was arrested by Depu- .ty United States Marshal West at Lamberts Point on a charge of coun terfeiting. A number of spuriout coins were found in Lees possession 1 M rs. Mary A. Knick, aged 82 years, of Collierstown, Rockbridge county is dead. She was a daughter of Mr and Mrs. William Armentrout and re sided during her whole life in th house in which she was born and died. Her husband, William Knick, died from the effects of a wound which h received in the battle of Chancellors ville, in May, 1863. Three sons survive her. After spending seven months in th inaccessible mountains of Tazewell county in order to avoid the officer! of the law, Thomas K. Leedy, t wealthy farmer, rode into Tazewe! and surrendered to, the sheriff, whe met him by appointment at the horn of State Senator J. N. Harman, whe will act as his counsel. In Januarj last according to the charge, Leed shot and killed Walter Harris, a pas senger on a train, near Graham. H immediately took to the mountains and the officers found it impossible tc arrest him. Finally, however, Leedj grew tired of being a fugitive fronr justice and agreed to give himself up In addition to being charged with the killing of Harris, Leedys defendant in a suit for damages amounting tc 10,000 brought by the relatives 01 th dead man. His trial on the charge ol murder will take place next month It is thought that Leedy will be ac quitted. He is a man well-known ir the Southwest. He posses great phy sical strength and exceptional skill in the use of the revolver and rifle. A sensational horsewhipping occur red on the streets of Leesburg ir which Mayor S. Carroll Chancelloi played the role of victim. Mrs. Geo Ferguson, who had charged the mayo with slandering her, wielded the wea pon, and mayor in defending himsell struck Mrs. .Ferguson with his cane The community has been thrown intc a perfect fever of excitement in conse quence vof the affair. It seems that about a year ago the mayor boarded at the home of Mrs. Ferguson. Re cently anonymous letters have beer, circulated concerning his conduct, and the mayor accused Mrs. Ferguson ol being their author. Harry Hoover, a young blacksmith living in Basic City, and working ir Staunton, was run over by a C.  O train while on his way to work. H later died. One foot and one arm were cut off and he was badly cut about the head and body. He was.2 years of age and has a wife at Basic It is thought he was riding a freight and tried to jump off before reaching the station, when he fell under the train. The first case under the new drug law came up Thursday when a Rich mond druggist was fined 25 for the sale of cocaine to a victim of the co caine habit. The police justice an nounced that in the future the fine would be 100 for each offense. The last Legislature passed a law forbid ding the sale of cocaine to any per sons except physicians, dentists and druggists. In Richmond many of the victims of the drug are young boys.
